message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and lab findings consistent with acute appendicitis. The next best step in management is an ultrasound of the appendix to confirm the diagnosis and plan for surgical intervention if needed. A pelvic exam would not be the most appropriate next step in management in this scenario. An upper gastrointestinal series would not be helpful in diagnosing or managing acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest acute appendicitis. Ultrasound of the appendix is the next best step in management to confirm the diagnosis. Pelvic exam may be considered but should not delay diagnosis and treatment. Upper gastrointestinal series is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and lab results are consistent with acute appendicitis. Ultrasound of the appendix is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Pelvic exam is not necessary unless other causes are suspected. Ultrasound of the pelvis and upper gastrointestinal series are not appropriate for the suspected diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, vital signs, and lab results suggest acute appendicitis. Ultrasound of the pelvis is the appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes of the symptoms. A pelvic exam may not provide enough information, an upper gastrointestinal series is not necessary for the diagnosis, and ultrasound of the appendix is not a common imaging modality for appendicitis.

Ultrasound of the appendix would be the best next step in the management of this patient to confirm the diagnosis. Pelvic exam and upper gastrointestinal series would not be helpful in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis.

Ultrasound of the appendix can confirm the diagnosis and is the next best step in management. A pelvic exam may also be performed but it does not specifically test for appendicitis. An upper gastrointestinal series and ultrasound of the pelvis are not relevant to the suspected diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest acute appendicitis, which is confirmed by ultrasound of the appendix. Pelvic exam is not necessary as the patient’s symptoms and lab results already suggest appendicitis. Ultrasound of the pelvis is not necessary as it will not help in identifying the cause of the symptoms. Upper gastrointestinal series is not necessary as it is used to diagnose conditions such as peptic ulcer, reflux disease, and gastric distension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of acute appendicitis, with focal tenderness and guarding in the right lower quadrant, and laboratory findings of elevated WBC and neutrophils. Ultrasound of the pelvis can help confirm the diagnosis by visualizing the appendix. Pelvic exam is not necessary for diagnosis, and upper gastrointestinal series is not relevant for appendicitis.
